Award.AwardTitle: CRCNS: Collaborative Research: Mapping and Control of Large-Scale Neural Dynamics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Brain stimulation is currently being used to treat a variety of cognitive, neurological, and psychiatric disorders, including depression, Parkinson's disease, and schizophrenia. Despite this broad use, how brain stimulation works remains largely a mystery. This project aims to address this gap in understanding by studying and modeling how neural processes change with brain stimulation. The investigators aim to develop criteria by which to evaluate and optimize stimulation-based treatments of neurological and psychiatric disorders. To accompany the scientific advances, the investigators will engage in educational efforts to bring the research to the classroom and to enhance cross-institutional opportunities for students. The investigators will place special emphasis on mentoring and encouraging women and minorities on the academic path in science and engineering. In addition, the investigators are combining their efforts in the Skirkanich Internship in Network Visualization, which hosts undergraduate art students each summer.

The investigators propose a new set of mathematical techniques to describe and predict neural processes and how they change with brain stimulation. Investigators at the University of California at Riverside (one of the most ethnically diverse research-intensive institutions in the U.S.) and the University of Pennsylvania will collaborate on theoretical, computational, and experimental research with three main research initiatives: (1) static and dynamic modeling of complex neural dynamics, identification of multi-resolution regions of interest in the human brain, the nature of their interconnections, and their function in observed cognitive dynamics; (2) analysis of network-wide dynamic properties of neural systems, characterization of brain regions based on controllability metrics, and design of non-disruptive control algorithms for the modulation of complex neural processes; (3) validation of models and control strategies in a wide variety of empirical settings to engineer and predict the outcomes of clinical interventions in neurological and psychiatric disorders. The success of this project will enable a deepened understanding of complex neurobiological systems, construct novel maps of the human brain and its dynamic processes, and develop non-disruptive control techniques for therapeutic brain stimulation protocols.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The last years have witnessed a heavily increased use of different forms of brain stimulations to diagnose, monitor, and treat neurological and psychiatric disorders. While effective, the fundamental principles behind the success of brain stimulation remain unclear, and most stimulation methods still rely on exhaustive tuning procedures. A fundamental obstacle preventing the development of rigorous and systematic neurological treatments is the lack of accurate computational models and theories to predict the impact of neurostimulation on brain processes. Such models would ultimately allow us to generalize and optimize the effects of brain stimulation across clinical cohorts. 

In this project we have taken the first major steps to fill this gap. In particular, we have used empirical scans of the human brain to construct simplified dynamic models of the human brain. Our models reflect the anatomical interconnected organization of the human brain, and rely on the tantalizing theory that, because of its structure, the human brain behaves as a network system akin to those studied in mechanical and electrical engineering. Using our models, we have developed a rigorous framework based on control and network theories to identify which regions of the human brain are more susceptible to external stimulation, how external stimuli propagate across the entire brain, what control trajectories may be better suited to address certain neurological disorders, and how differences in the brain anatomy affect learning and executive function. We have also used our models to understand how different brain regions can synchronize, that is, showing coherent neural activity, over time. These results are not only of theoretical interest, but they also allow us to create a link between the anatomy of the brain, and the onset of certain neurological disorders linked to abnormalities in the synchronization activity.  Our results in this direction are the first of their kind, and they open an entirely new way to study the human brain, which has rapidly spread across the network, controls, and neuroscience communities. 

Perhaps the most surprising result of our project is the fact that the human brain is ?theoretically controllable? from a stimulus affecting a single brain area. In loose words, it is theoretically possible to manipulate brain-wide activity by locally affecting a single brain area. Then, this results opens the door to the development of novel targeted medicine and interventions to alter brain-wide processes. However, our study also shows that the brain is difficult to control in practice, and that simultaneous interventions at multiple locations may be necessary to practically alter the brain state in a meaningful way.

At a more fundamental level, this project has created a set of theories to analyze, design, and optimally manipulate dynamical systems evolving over a network structure. For instance, we have shown how the structure of a network affects our ability to manipulate a process evolving over such structure, what network properties are mostly responsible for performance and robustness, and how the network parameters should be adapted to guarantee controllability and performance. These results are now an integral part of the growing field of network control theory. Because networks appear in virtually all domains of science and engineering, and are an accurate representation of a number of natural, social, and technological processes, our results are broadly applicable beyond the scenario considered in the proposal, and have in fact rapidly been disseminated and adopted across different scientific communities.

Because of the interdisciplinary nature of our study, this project has created several opportunities to bring together experts from traditionally isolated fields, such as the controls and neuroscience communities. We have organized invited and tutorial sessions in occasion of several international meetings, where we have promoted a dialogue between the communities, and have started the development of theoretically rigorous methods to address problems arising in the neuroscience. We believe that it is a successful outcome of this project that several tracks at the major controls conferences are now addressing problems that have a direct neuroscientific application.

This project was the first one to promote the use and development of network- and control-theoretic methods to study the human brain, its organization, and its functions. While our results constitute a milestone in this directions, our study has clearly shown the shortcomings of current theories and methods, and the clear need for additional coordinated efforts and research to develop novel rigorous theories. In our opinion, our initial study of the synchronization properties of the brain is perhaps the aspect that shows the most substantial promise and that needs the most attention, as we are planning moving forward.
